data.title: Improved clarity of Editor not responding actions
data.body:
### Description of the Change

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

Changed the label on the positive button of the "Editor is not responding" alert dialog from "Close" to "Force Close" because "Close" might imply closing the Alert/Dialog instead of the editor, whereas "Force Close" better describes the action that button will take.

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

Other strings may be "Force Quit" or "End Process" or "Close Editor"

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

This change is a tweak to the core strings.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

Makes a (minor) improvement to user experience and reduces decision fatigue for end users. 

### Possible Drawbacks

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

Slight (neglibile) increase in file size due to longer string.

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->

Translation/localization will need to be updated elsewhere.

data.title: ctrl+t bug on linux
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
I'm using atom on Linux (elementary loki), and have noticed that the ctrl+t command only works to open a search modal when I remove the cursor from any open text documents and click into the window tab bar.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open atom, open multiple text documents in one window
2. cursor in one of the docs, execute ctrl+t
3. click into the document tab bar at the top, execute ctrl+t again

**Expected behavior:** pressing ctrl+t with focus on atom opens new-file search modal at top of window

**Actual behavior:** pressing ctrl+t only opens search modal if cursor is removed from open text document by clicking into the window tab bar

**Reproduces how often:** 90%

### Versions

#bug

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Feature Request: Track which screen to display windows on
data.body: It'd be neat if, when I press the [Restart] button, Atom restarted on the same monitor that it was on, in the same place even.  Sometimes I have 2 editor windows on different screens. It'd be nice if Atom tracked all of the display-related information.

data.title: [v1.19] adding blockDecoration makes editor rendering odd
data.body:
![block-decoration-issue-on-v1 9](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/26959598-c1407704-4d0b-11e7-922c-66d4cca79aae.gif)


### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Block decoration occupy two screen row, and after I render block decoration, cursor, line-gutter shows incorrect place.

Tried last build on #14435, (commit: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14435/commits/a5f4472f5d422d6185c6952ae2c3a6cef68eec1d) which is last commit before merged to master.

- [Download link](https://4126-3228505-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/Users/distiller/atom/out/atom-mac.zip)
- version

```
Atom    : 1.19.0-dev-a5f4472
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Steps to Reproduce

I can reproduce with **safe-mode**

1. open editor, insert three lines of text whatever (`row0\nrow1\nrow3`)
2. open chrome dev-tools and paste following js code.

```javascript
(function reproduceIssue() {
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  const cursorRow = editor.getCursorBufferPosition().row
  const item = document.createElement("span")
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]"
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([cursorRow, 0])
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: item })
})()
```

3. See **line-gutter**, insert text to row0, row1, row2 and see cursor is shown in incorrect screen position.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

can edit normal way
block decoration occupy one screen row as like in previous release.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

rendering become odd.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

always

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

My [narrow](https://atom.io/packages/narrow) package directly affected this issue.
Here is gif with same-build-Atom.

The first line's buttons are items in single block decoration.
The cursor is row 0 in previous release, but with latest-build, cursor and lines render incorrectly because of this issue.

![block-decoration-issue-on-v1 9-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/26959759-cb225ab6-4d0c-11e7-9f9b-61d979b032ad.gif)

data.title: EDITOR IS NOT RESPONDING!!!
data.body:
### Description

This is happening for months its freaking annoying!
Editor is not responding every time I close atom with files left opened and then I try to open it again, the editor is stuck I always have to clear the state to fix this!

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open some large project files 4-5 with over 10000 lines of code
2. Close the editor
3. Restart PC
4. Open atom from the desktop link
5. Atom is stuck

I expect atom to work

Atom gets stuck and its not responding

99.99%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Is there are a way to stop atom from saving the state?? or auto closing the tabs on exit?
Also: I have auto compile less plugin and a theme (not a chance its related as in safe mode I have same problem)

data.title: Add verticalScrollMargin to configurable settings.
data.body:
### Description of the Change
Vertical scroll margin was already a feature, but it was hard coded to 2. This PR adds it as a configurable setting.
Primary changes that had to be made:
src/text-editor.coffee: Added verticalScrollMargin to constructor/copy/update.
src/config-schema.js: Added verticalScrollMargin as an editor property with default of 2 and a description of the feature.
src/text-editor-registry.js: Added verticalScrollMargin editor param.
spec/text-editor-spec.coffee: Added tests for the feature.

### Alternate Designs

There is a workaround mentioned in issue [#11799](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11799), but this PR simply adds it as a configurable setting.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

It's an existing feature in core, but its value is hard coded. In other editors this is usually either a configurable feature or non-existent (i.e. 0 margin).

### Benefits

People who are used to the lack of a vertical scroll margin in other editors, or who wish to customize it, can now easily modify the vertical scroll margin size in the settings.

### Possible Drawbacks

None that I'm aware of.

### Applicable Issues

[#11799](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11799)

data.title: Ctrl-alt-'letter' Keybindings do not appear as a shortcut
data.body:
![menu_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27342440/26912866-71f377fe-4c17-11e7-83e4-00276419b9dc.png)
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Ctrl-alt-'Letter' keybindings do not appear as shortcuts in menu items.
All other key bindings appear as shortcuts except ctrl-alt. What's up with that?

Importantly, this only happens on Windows, and I have tried it out with both 1.16 and 1.17 versions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create Sample Package
2. The keybinding for toggle is ctrl-alt-o
3. Cannot be seen as a shortcut in the menu, Packages>my-package>toggle

data.title: Add methods for observing dock visibility
data.body:
This adds an `onDidChangeVisible()` and `observeVisible()` method to docks so that other objects can be notified when they're toggled.

Since this functionality covers the `didHide()` callback use case, I removed that.

One thing I'd like to discuss is the semantics of this. In the original docks PR, I had avoided calling this "visible" because it'll actually be false while the dock is visible but being animated closed. If you're using this API, for example, to show or hide contents of an item, you could wind up with surprising results.

data.title: Misaligned tiles on editor when opening atom with previously large file open
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Misaligned tiles on text editor when opening atom with previously large file open


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download the following [python script](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/ungb/e7fc5218852ccf87be860f25d7e693b0/raw/0a8dd047d98cdeb3cd01224445c3d2e6cc8e5b1e/fileMaker.py)
2. Open terminal and run the python script you downloaded to generate a 74mb file
`python fileMaker.py`
3. You should have a file called `70mbFileTest.cpp`, run `atom 70mbFileTest.cpp` to open this file on atom.
4. scroll to the last line of this file (cmd+down arrow) on mac. 
5. Completely exit out of atom.
6. Open atom(should restore previous state)




**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
text editor lines should be aligned correctly  


**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Misaligned tiles on the editor

**NOTE:** If you close and open the file again it shows up correctly.  This only occurs when restoring state, If you open a blank editor and restore the session it to the existing editor it doesn't repro, but does when it opens a new window.  


Screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/26903834-f7429de2-4b93-11e7-951b-c9c0b8d52208.png)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%, but only with large files and exact repro provided.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0-dev-0cd482cbf
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information
Haven't tested on windows or linux, but on Mac Sierra 10.12.5 (16F73)
Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Don't try to measure lines that don't exist
data.body:
By the time that the animation frame is delivered, the requested autoscroll position could not exist anymore. This could cause the editor component to measure a non-existent line and, as a result, throw an exception.

With this commit we will always ignore measurements for screen lines that do not exist.

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Scroll issue 1.17.2 OSX
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I can't scroll left pane with trackpad on mac osx v. 10.12.14. I just don't see the scrollbar, but if jump between files with arrows everything is ok. 
In previous version 1.16.0 x64 scroll on trackpad works as expected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom in full window
2. Open much projects and open many folder trees
3. Try to scroll with trackpad (two fingers), and nothing happens

**Expected behavior:** Scroll left pane content

**Actual behavior:** No scroll at all

**Reproduces how often:** on new version 1.17.2 every time

### Versions
`$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0`

### Additional Information
Same issue happens on 1.18-beta.

But works as expected on previous stable release 1.16
`$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0`

osx version

`Darwin MacBook-zh.local 16.5.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.5.0: Fri Mar  3 16:52:33 PST 2017; root:xnu-3789.51.2~3/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64`

data.title: "Save As" for new file doesn't default to a sensible directory location
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When creating a new file and hitting Save, the save dialog doesn't seem to have any particular directory set and defaults to a platform-dependent location.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new untitled file
2. Save it

**Expected behavior:**

"Save As" dialog should default to a sensible location (most likely the project root, which definitely _used_ to be the behaviour)

**Actual behavior:**

**On Ubuntu**, Save dialog opens at "Recently Used", sometimes making it a pain to find the logical place to save the file.

**On mac**, seems to default to project root directory, but **only** for the first window opened (I assume it defaults to the process's cwd)

Can't speak for windows right at the moment I'm afraid

Directory is set fine if you're hitting "save as" from a file that already exists.

**Reproduces how often:**

Every time

### Versions

Currently 1.18 beta but basically every version since #13978 was reported

### Additional Information

I guess #13978 got closed because the desired behaviour was fixed on mac for the first-opened window and for already-existing files. Looks like this was also reported in #14304 but that was closed because it didn't follow the template.

data.title: apm.sh script generates incorrect paths on cygwin
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Basically the same as issue #9169, only for apm.sh rather than atom.sh.

When `apm` or `apm.sh` is run from a cygwin shell, it produces an incorrect path to the implementation .js file, producing an error that looks like this:

```
module.js:471
    throw err;
    ^

Error: Cannot find module 'C:\cygdrive\c\Users\admin\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.17.2\resources\app\apm\lib\cli.js'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:469:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:417:25)
    at Module.runMain (module.js:604:10)
    at run (bootstrap_node.js:394:7)
    at startup (bootstrap_node.js:149:9)
    at bootstrap_node.js:509:3
```
Presumably, apm.sh should have a windows-specific stub that corrects for cygwin/msys paths, similarly to the way atom.sh currently handles things.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. On a fresh install
2. Open cygwin bash
3. Run `/cygdrive/c/Users/[your username]/AppData/Local/atom/bin/apm`

**Expected behavior:** Should behave that same as if you run `/cygdrive/c/Users/[your username]/AppData/Local/atom/bin/apm.cmd`

**Actual behavior:** Produces error message quoted above.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.8.3
visual studio 2015
cygcheck (cygwin) 2.7.0
GNU bash, version 4.4.12(3)-release (x86_64-unknown-cygwin)
```

data.title: Fix Docks docs
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

Fixes some issues with the new Docks documentation.  In particular, the documentation to `get{Left|Right|Bottom}Dock` was pointing to the wrong class and the methods themselves weren't public.

Please note: While adding documentation to the dock methods, I noticed that while `WorkspaceCenter` had docs for its individual methods, it did not have documentation for the class itself and therefore was not showing up as part of the API.  Therefore I've added a short blurb to the class.

The documentation I added was based off my best judgement and the comments for similar classes/methods; please feel free to improve them.

### Alternate Designs

N/A

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because the documentation is in core.

### Benefits

Better documentation.

### Possible Drawbacks

None.

### Applicable Issues

Fixes #14728

I have no clue how to test this.

data.title: Docks documentation points to non-existent get{Left|Right|Bottom}Dock methods
data.body:
(Issue template does not apply)

The [Docks](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.17.2/Dock) documentation links to `getLeftDock`, `getRightDock`, and `getBottomDock`.  However, there are two problems: those methods exist in Workspace and not Dock; and those methods are not publicly documented.

data.title: ⬆️  Update packages to populate status bar for pending editor pane items
data.body:
This PR upgrades the packages associated with the issue described in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14648.

Now that https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14695 is merged, and now that we have new releases of the [associated packages](https://github.com/atom/status-bar/issues/194#issuecomment-306206730), this PR updates Atom to use those new releases.

Associated PRs:

- https://github.com/atom/status-bar/pull/195
- https://github.com/atom/grammar-selector/pull/45
- https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/pull/49
- https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector/pull/46
- https://github.com/atom/github/pull/905

data.title: When you create a new file through the command line it does not show up in the package explorer
data.body:
Hi,
  In my Ubuntu Linux 16.04 install with atom I have a project folder added to the project. However when I create a new file in the project using the command line there is no way to see it in atom. Even when I try to open up a new file I am still not able to see it. 

Thanks!
